snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay:
Here is the formula used by the Norwegian Institute of Public Health - NIPH (Folkehelseinstituttet - FHI) to find the infection rate: RE = βₑcₑDₑx
Where:
RE (with a downset E): The Effective Reproduction Rate
Contageousness x
Contact frequency x
Duration of infectious period x
The number of receptive people
If the contageousness is under one, the epidemic will die out. If the contageousness is above one, the epidemic will grow.

The FHI assumes an RE number of 1.3. Additionally it is going by these values:
Latency: 3 days (the period from when you catch the disease until you become contageous)
Contageous period: 4 days
Duration of hospitalization: 10 days
Duration in intensive care: 15 additional days
Proportion of infected that become sick: 33%
Proportion of sick who are hospitalized: 4%
Proportion of hospitalized that need intensive care: 25%

These numbers have come under heavy criticism by epidemological experts, including PhD/GP Gunnhild Alvik Nyborg, who consider the RE to be significantly higher, and even higher than in Wuhan because the measures against the pandemic are lax in Norway. Nyborg said the RE number was instead 2-3 in Wuhan, but she considers that the RE number could be over 3 for Oslo, Norway.

She claimed that the NIPH has used the common flu as their baseline, while this is a completely different beast. Further more, the expert said that there is reason to believe that the virus is spread through aerosols that may linger in the air for up to an hour after an infected has caughed or sneezed, or even stood there and breathed, so people also need facemasks to limit the spread of the virus.

Nyborg also criticizes the NIPH estimate for how many could need hospitalization in Norway. Obviously, when the fatality rate in Italy is approaching 7%, you have to assume that also that many has needed intensive care. Then only 4% hospitalized does not make any sense. It has to be higher.

PhD/GP Gunnhild Alvik Nyborg is an epidemological expert from Oslo University Hospital, Rikshospitalet (the National Hospital). She's now a Virology scientist on T-cells, with an additional diploma in Social Economy.

Souce: https://tv.nrk.no/serie/debatten/202003/NNFA51031720/avspiller
snippet.textOriginal:
Here is the formula used by the Norwegian Institute of Public Health - NIPH (Folkehelseinstituttet - FHI) to find the infection rate: RE = βₑcₑDₑx 
Where:
RE (with a downset E): The Effective Reproduction Rate
Contageousness x
Contact frequency x
Duration of infectious period x
The number of receptive people
If the contageousness is under one, the epidemic will die out. If the contageousness is above one, the epidemic will grow. 

The FHI assumes an RE number of 1.3. Additionally it is going by these values:
Latency: 3 days (the period from when you catch the disease until you become contageous)
Contageous period: 4 days
Duration of hospitalization: 10 days
Duration in intensive care: 15 additional days
Proportion of infected that become sick: 33%
Proportion of sick who are hospitalized: 4%
Proportion of hospitalized that need intensive care: 25%

These numbers have come under heavy criticism by epidemological experts, including PhD/GP Gunnhild Alvik Nyborg, who consider the RE to be significantly higher, and even higher than in Wuhan because the measures against the pandemic are lax in Norway. Nyborg said the RE number was instead 2-3 in Wuhan, but she considers that the RE number could be over 3 for Oslo, Norway. 

She claimed that the NIPH has used the common flu as their baseline, while this is a completely different beast. Further more, the expert said that there is reason to believe that the virus is spread through _aerosols_ that may linger in the air for up to an hour after an infected has caughed or sneezed, or even stood there and breathed, so people also need facemasks to limit the spread of the virus. 

Nyborg also criticizes the NIPH estimate for how many could need hospitalization in Norway. Obviously, when the fatality rate in Italy is approaching 7%, you have to assume that also that many has needed intensive care. Then only 4% hospitalized does not make any sense. It has to be higher.

PhD/GP Gunnhild Alvik Nyborg is an epidemological expert from Oslo University Hospital, Rikshospitalet (the National Hospital). She's now a Virology scientist on T-cells, with an additional diploma in Social Economy.

Souce: https://tv.nrk.no/serie/debatten/202003/NNFA51031720/avspiller

snippet.textDisplay:
Math homework questions:

How might the unrecorded cases of COVID-19 change the data of exponential growth?

The data used in this video was from the overall cases of Corona globally. What would each country’s exponential growth look like? What information could be deducted by comparing countries with smaller exponential growth to those with larger?

Are there any examples of continuous exponential growth in the real world, in which an inflection point is never reached?

What information can we use from countries who have already reached inflection points? At what point in time can we calculate America to reach this point? 

Do countries with bigger populations have larger or smaller rates of exponential growth?
snippet.textOriginal:

The data used in this video was from the overall cases of Corona globally. What would each country’s exponential growth look like? What information could be deducted by comparing countries with smaller exponential growth to those with larger?

Are there any examples of continuous exponential growth in the real world, in which an inflection point is never reached?

What information can we use from countries who have already reached inflection points? At what point in time can we calculate America to reach this point? 

Do countries with bigger populations have larger or smaller rates of exponential growth?

snippet.textDisplay: 7993 is logarithmically closer to fifty million than to one. It takes about 13.0 doublings to get from 1 to 7993. It takes only about 12.6 doublings to get from 7993 to 50000000. 7993 is the current worldwide count of coronavirus deaths according the live update on Roylab Stats channel.

snippet.textDisplay:
Math Assignment Questions:
What might cause this constant of exponential growth to remain at around 1.20x cases per day?
What makes it difficult for us as humans to identify a situation of exponential growth?
What factors cause true exponentials to be unable to exist in the real world?
What creates an inflection point in a real-world scenario?
Why do simulations where changes between communities occur not change growth significantly? This doesn’t seem to be consistent with real world epidemics.
snippet.textOriginal:
Math Assignment Questions:
What might cause this constant of exponential growth to remain at around 1.20x cases per day?
What makes it difficult for us as humans to identify a situation of exponential growth?
What factors cause true exponentials to be unable to exist in the real world?
What creates an inflection point in a real-world scenario?
Why do simulations where changes between communities occur not change growth significantly? This doesn’t seem to be consistent with real world epidemics.

snippet.textDisplay:
But if we consider the differential equation d(N(t))/d(t) = (Ep)*(N(t)), it would be N(t) = e^((Ep)*t) * N(0).
I think both this derivation and the one in the video are correct, but not equivalent. But WHY?
I think it could possibly be that on using calculus, we are probably considering every point in time, but in the solution from video, we are considering the total after each day, i.e., a case of continuous and discrete variables respectively. But still, why is the 'e' appearing in the continuous case?
Still, I feel as if there is some sort of discontinuity between the two. If someone could somehow draw some kind of parallelism between these two formulas to show if they are, even to some extent, equivalent, it'd be great!
snippet.textOriginal:
But if we consider the differential equation d(N(t))/d(t) = (Ep)*(N(t)), it would be N(t) = e^((Ep)*t) * N(0).
I think both this derivation and the one in the video are correct, but not equivalent. But WHY?
I think it could possibly be that on using calculus, we are probably considering every point in time, but in the solution from video, we are considering the total after each day, i.e., a case of continuous and discrete variables respectively. But still, why is the 'e' appearing in the continuous case?
Still, I feel as if there is some sort of discontinuity between the two. If someone could somehow draw some kind of parallelism between these two formulas to show if they are, even to some extent, equivalent, it'd be great!

snippet.textDisplay:
As for when does it slow down; It appears right now that about 10.5% of those exposed show symptoms so considering a world population of 8*10^9, this would mean that 8.4*10^8 are vulnerable to this infection. This means that if everyone on earth was exposed about 840,000,000 would get sick, a small portion of that would need hospitalization and a smaller portion would perish. In your graph at 3:20 it would level off just before the 1 billion mark.
Morbidity and mortality rates, as reported by Wikipedia as of writing this comment is 0.2% for ages 20 - 50, 0.8% for ages 51 - 60, 3.6% for ages 61 - 70, 8.5% for ages 71 - 80, 15.4% for ages 80+. This could change by the time you read this. That is just for the people who show symptoms. There is also an infection to first symptoms delay of anywhere from 2 - 5 days and 15 days from first symptoms to death on average.
This of course is greatly oversimplified

snippet.textDisplay: So, does this mean that the projections from the experts (as said by the news) of 50 to 60 percent of the worlds population getting it might be inaccurate if all precaution measures are taken seriously and work? Because, correct me if I'm wrong or missing something but, if that is still accurate and the death rate remains 2 to 4 percent that does still mean that the eventual number could be anywhere between 77 million to 184 million deaths. That would actually be WW2 territory or even way beyond (the total death in ww2 are estimated to be around 69 to 84 millon, that includes direct and inderect deaths). And IF 3:15 would turn out to be correct in even the slightest way, since a vaccine is said to be at least 1 to 1,5 years away it sould easily have plenty of time to get up to that 50 to 60 percent infection rate even if it would be far less. But all this is still not to mention the danger of the virus mutating to an even more deadly and efficent form, which it already did. It has mutated from the S-type to the L-type and that does turn out to be more infectious and aggressive. Also they've said (in news) that scientist do not rule out the possibillity (and actually think it is more or less inevitable) that the virus will mutate further and become possibly even more infectious and aggressive. Even if we'd be able to keep the worldwide infection rate at 10 percent, that would still mean some 15 to 30 million people would die from this. To put this in perspective, WW1 death are estimated to be about 20 million, NY state has about 20 million inhabitants, California state has about 30 million inhabitants, Texas state has a little less that 30 million inhabitants. You get the picture. So unless me somehow manage to stop this it's going to be some seriously apocoliptic stuff.

snippet.textDisplay:
Very nice exposition!
I like how you introduced key factors in the growth behavior one by one. And as usual, the graphic illustrations were top-notch in showing what's happening.
And how you introduced the mathematics that limits, in real-world cases, what starts out as exponential growth, which can in no case, ever continue indefinitely.

But I was waiting for another factor that you never got to – recovery.
A viral disease has a time course, and after a certain length of time, in most cases, an individual who had it, becomes both no longer infectious to others, and immune to re-infection.

Can you maybe do a follow-up to explain the effect of these considerations on the course of the pandemic?

Nevertheless, thanks for this video. It makes the picture a lot clearer!

Fred
snippet.textOriginal:
Very nice exposition!
I like how you introduced key factors in the growth behavior one by one. And as usual, the graphic illustrations were top-notch in showing what's happening.
And how you introduced the mathematics that limits, in real-world cases, what starts out as exponential growth, which can in no case, ever continue indefinitely.

But I was waiting for another factor that you never got to – recovery.
A viral disease has a time course, and after a certain length of time, in most cases, an individual who had it, becomes both no longer infectious to others, and immune to re-infection.

Can you maybe do a follow-up to explain the effect of these considerations on the course of the pandemic?

Nevertheless, thanks for this video. It makes the picture a lot clearer!

Fred

How much do travel restrictions, hand hygiene, social distancing and imperfect quarantines affect the growth factor? I mean in terms of actual numbers. Is this a difference between 1 billion and 1.2 billion people getting infected or the difference between 1billion and 1 million?

I'm certain there are epidemiologists who know the answer to this, but I don't know how to search the epidemiology literature.
snippet.textOriginal:

I'm certain there are epidemiologists who know the answer to this, but I don't know how to search the epidemiology literature.

This video is linked from a group of physicians (congrats @3Blue1Brown!):
https://www.kevinmd.com/blog/2020/03/a-covid-19-coronavirus-update-from-concerned-physicians.html

Regarding the pinned comment at top about "reported" vs. "actual" infections:
https://medium.com/@tomaspueyo/coronavirus-act-today-or-people-will-die-f4d3d9cd99ca

Washington Post simulations of how disease spreads during a pandemic:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/

snippet.textDisplay:
"With less people affected and dying than from the yearly seasonal flu, this "virus" is being hyped way out of proportion on purpose as they are now testing out quarantining entire huge cities like Shanghai and Wuhan, and the sheeple seem to be following suit as expected. This is being used as a vehicle to push/test draconian government measures that would never be rolled out otherwise.
They are now also developing a vaccine which will likely be forced on people one way or another. 

Here in Thailand 90% of people are wearing face-masks, there are temperature checks to get into department stores, tumbleweeds blowing through airports, and the most disturbing to me is the biggest bank in Thailand just closed all foreign exchange branches urging the public to stop using paper money claiming it is helping spread the virus and is pushing for everyone to use cashless currencies. This CV is serving better than fake alien invasion as far as rolling out the NWO plan. Successfully quarantining entire huge cities with dozens of millions of people like Shanghai and Wuhan without a hitch is scary. And the scariest thing is how sheepishly the people believe everything their lying governments and medias tell them."  - Eric Dubay


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRKiI94Ghfc

snippet.textDisplay: I know i have Corona now, andi can say: "im not afraid of it". Im 48 years and i dont feel so bad. Worst part is i have to stay inside my Apartment for 14 days, but that is a minor isue.  And i cant visit my mother who is over 70 years old
